html: @iivmok When you're not running with runserver, Django won't serve your static assets. You'll want to run collectstatic, then add a static-map directive to your uWSGI config (like static-map = /static=/my/shoop/dir/var/static). The same stands for /media.
text: @iivmok When you're not running with `runserver`, Django won't serve your static assets. You'll want to run `collectstatic`, then add a `static-map` directive to your uWSGI config (like `static-map = /static=/my/shoop/dir/var/static`). The same stands for `/media`.

html: Yeah @elnygren , Shoop uses the usual Django template override mechanism, i.e. with the appdirs loader it looks through INSTALLED_APPS in order and uses the first template in that application's templates directory that matches the path.
text: Yeah @elnygren , Shoop uses the usual Django template override mechanism, i.e. with the appdirs loader it looks through `INSTALLED_APPS` in order and uses the first template in that application's `templates` directory that matches the path.

html: @elnygren The actual viewsets provided by the core by default don't actually use that factory, since they need "auth" of their own: https://github.com/shoopio/shoop/blob/master/shoop/core/api/products.py#L37
text: @elnygren The actual viewsets provided by the core by default don't actually use that factory, since they need "auth" of their own: https://github.com/shoopio/shoop/blob/master/shoop/core/api/products.py#L37

html: But for your project, yeah, you probably want to declare a router and viewsets by yourself if you want to customize things; the defaults are just defaults for simple use cases at present.
text: But for your project, yeah, you probably want to declare a router and viewsets by yourself if you want to customize things; the defaults are just defaults for simple use cases at present.

html: (well, not all viewsets anyway. https://github.com/shoopio/shoop/blob/master/shoop/core/api/__init.py)
text: (well, not _all_ viewsets anyway. https://github.com/shoopio/shoop/blob/master/shoop/core/api/__init__.py)

html: And to answer your actual question, @elnygren, I have to admit I'm not 100% sure about API completeness. At the very least, there's no RESTful API for basket (shopping cart) handling as it's a "frontend" thing (which is handled by the shoop.front app, which your SPA would replace).
text: And to answer your actual question, @elnygren, I have to admit I'm not 100% sure about API completeness. At the very least, there's no RESTful API for basket (shopping cart) handling as it's a "frontend" thing (which is handled by the `shoop.front` app, which your SPA would replace).

html: @dtnmr Multiple shops is not implemented on the Front yet. Currently the front middleware just selects the first shop with Shop.objects.first(). But we probably won't use django.contrib.sites for multi-shop. In the Shoop world, the Shop model is analogous to django.contrib.sites's Site model.
text: @dtnmr Multiple shops is not implemented on the Front yet. Currently the front middleware just selects the first shop with Shop.objects.first(). But we probably won't use django.contrib.sites for multi-shop. In the Shoop world, the Shop model is analogous to django.contrib.sites's Site model.

html: @dtnmr you shouldn't need 'shoop.themes' and move 'shoop.thees.default_theme' and 'shoop.themes.classic_gray' before 'shoop.front'. That should do it.
text: @dtnmr you shouldn't need 'shoop.themes' and move 'shoop.thees.default_theme' and 'shoop.themes.classic_gray' before 'shoop.front'. That should do it.

html: The INSTALLED_APPS order matters, because both shoop.front and the active theme provide an index.jinja and Django selects the one to render based on the INSTALLED_APPS order.

html: Pretty sure this happens because of your settings. Please check https://github.com/shoopio/shoop/blob/master/shoop_workbench/settings/base_settings.py and change your installed apps order based on this. You don't have to add apps just check the ordering. Also check that you have front middleware added.
text: Pretty sure this happens because of your settings. You don't have to add apps just check the ordering. Also check that you have front middleware added.

html: Hi developers. I have an ecommerce project with some features. I want to ask: Does Shoop support features? The features: 1. Multiple website and custom domain; 2. Use mongodb; 3.custom theme of front (i see that  xtheme work well); 4.multi-shop with multi administrator, a shop is managed by an admin. Thanks.
text: Hi developers. I have an ecommerce project with some features. I want to ask: Does Shoop support features? The features: 1. Multiple website and custom domain; 2. Use mongodb; 3.custom theme of front (i see that  xtheme work well); 4.multi-shop with multi administrator, a shop is managed by an admin. Thanks.

html: Hi!
text: Hi!

html: @sondt87: 1. Yes, multiple sites can be implemented quite easily with the multishop support, but that will need some small work though. Custom domain: Yes , 2. How do you want to use MongoDB? For what? 3. Yes, you can create a custom theme. 4. What do you mean with multi-shop with multi-admin? Should each shop have a separate admin that cannot access other shops? (There is no such feature currently.)
text: @sondt87: 1. Yes, multiple sites can be implemented quite easily with the multishop support, but that will need some small work though. Custom domain: Yes , 2. How do you want to use MongoDB? For what? 3. Yes, you can create a custom theme. 4. What do you mean with multi-shop with multi-admin? Should each shop have a separate admin that cannot access other shops? (There is no such feature currently.)

My system have some features like Shopify: theme, manage product, manage order (Shoop had too)... But all the shops use same database. That is the difference. If relationship db is well performance, I will ignore MongoDB. Sorry about my English, it isn't well. Could you give me suggestion about my ecommerce system?

html: @sondt87 Are those thousands shops sharing the products or are you having possibly "thousands x hundreds" products?
text: @sondt87 Are those thousands shops sharing the products or are you having possibly "thousands x hundreds" products?

html: Since having e.g. 10000 shops might be possible, but if each have a different product set and there would be something like 100 million products, then its totally different.
text: Since having e.g. 10000 shops might be possible, but if each have a different product set and there would be something like 100 million products, then its totally different.

html: Anyway, thousands of shops in the same database would most probably need some kind of sharding for the database, but it is possible with SQL too.
text: Anyway, thousands of shops in the same database would most probably need some kind of sharding for the database, but it is possible with SQL too.

html: @sondt87 Hi. This is unfortenately that Demos are a bit outdated. As a quick fix as you noticed, adding those fields fixes the problem.

html:
The contents of the ~/.transifexrc are just: 

[https://www.transifex.com]
hostname = https://www.transifex.com
password = your_password
token = 
username = your_user_name

you will to install Transifex client before executing tx command to pull the strings.. after pulling the strings, you must commit the changes in your repository and push them to the remote repository.. once the changes are in remote (your remote repository, the forked one).. create a pull request go here https://github.com/shoopio/shoop/compare and click on compare across forks selecting your repository and the created translation branch (YOUR_BRANCH_NAME)
text:
The contents of the `~/.transifexrc` are just: 
```
[https://www.transifex.com]
hostname = https://www.transifex.com
password = your_password
token = 
username = your_user_name
```

you will to install Transifex client before executing `tx` command to pull the strings.. after pulling the strings, you must commit the changes in your repository and push them to the remote repository.. once the changes are in remote (your remote repository, the forked one).. create a pull request go here `https://github.com/shoopio/shoop/compare` and click on *compare across forks* selecting your repository and the created translation branch (`YOUR_BRANCH_NAME`)

    ('en', 'English'),

    ('zh-hans', 'Simplified Chinese'),
    ('pt-br', 'Portuguese (Brazil)'),
]

html: null@1801405 There are different extension mechanisms for different extension points. 1-to-1 model extensions help with extending the data model; provides, as mentioned by @shawnadelic, are used as a sort of dependency injection/plugin registry method, and Django signals are used for eventing.
text: @1801405 There are different extension mechanisms for different extension points. 1-to-1 model extensions help with extending the data model; provides, as mentioned by @shawnadelic, are used as a sort of dependency injection/plugin registry method, and Django signals are used for eventing.

html: In addition, it's worth remembering that Shoop is after all just a constellation of regular Django apps, so you can, with reasonable effort, mix and match parts of it; for instance, there's nothing preventing you from writing your own shop frontend without using any of the views/URLs provided by shoop.front. On the other hand, if you just want a shop that works out-of-the-box, you can copy-paste shoop_workbench and start extending from there.
text: In addition, it's worth remembering that Shoop is after all just a constellation of regular Django apps, so you can, with reasonable effort, mix and match parts of it; for instance, there's nothing preventing you from writing your own shop frontend without using any of the views/URLs provided by `shoop.front`. On the other hand, if you just want a shop that works out-of-the-box, you can copy-paste `shoop_workbench` and start extending from there.

html:
Looks like I'm going to work with Shoop for the next 3-9 months, and I thought that I can contribute some part of my work into Shoop. But in that case probably I will need to discuss few thing with you.

At this moment I don't have complete plan of my work yet, but approximately it may looks like:

  • url with categories
    • I need it in format like "/games/actions/gta-5/"
    • my current idea is to try it with middleware (and cached in RAM list of categories), this way it can be optional for end user
    • also I will need to add in the admin panel opportunity to manually set a slug for products and categories
  • fully-featured digital products support
    • I created issue on github with kind of proposal, but probably I will need more than that
  • localise url for SEO
    • right know search engines unable to discover others language versions of Shoop, I think this is a critical problem
    • maybe through subdomain or djagno supported url prefix
  • product reviews & questions and answers
    • my front-end I planning to write in TypeScript, so maybe I won't create front-end for Shoop default theme
  • payment integration with liqpay.com and wmtransfer.com systems. maybe few others too.
  • xml-sitemap
  • probably I will want to extend your product parent/child system, because right know it's admin interface doesn't look comfortable for me
  • product filters in catalogue
  • integration with some django blog cms
  • script for import products and reviews from magento
  • ...

Order of work doesn't really important for me, but maybe I will begin from url with categories. Just because it probably won't require full understating of your system (which I still don't have).

And my first question will be: how do you look at PR like this one? As I said, it can be optional, maybe even work side-by-side with your implementation of url.

Looks like I'm going to work with Shoop for the next 3-9 months, and I thought that I can contribute some part of my work into Shoop. But in that case probably I will need to discuss few thing with you.

At this moment I don't have complete plan of my work yet, but approximately it may looks like:

html: First of all nice to hear that you are working with Shoop. We will check your tasks/features list more closely and will provide you some feedback or suggestions. I would suggest first you create your custom project over Shoop and build these features in it. After the feature/features you implemented is done. You can create PR:s to get those in the master too. The url categories sounds like you might not want to use all parts from shoop.front either. Maybe leave it all out or just override urls in there. We will also look into your question in Github too, but as an quick answer there is ProductType already implemented and you can add your custom attributes to it.

html:
We will also look into your question in Github too, but as an quick answer there is ProductType already implemented and you can add your custom attributes to it.

Do you mean ProductType for defining set of attributes? No, it is not exactly what I mean. For me it's just looks like Shoop targeting on physical products only:

  • required physical dimensions
  • required sending address on order
  • and so on...

I think it is maybe ok, but in that case every developer of digital shop will need to write a lot of customizations over it. Besides, plenty of other ecommerce solutions already have digital products integration by default, so some shop owners can set question like: "Why do we need suggested by you Shoop, which will require so many customizations, if we can just go with magento?".
text:
> We will also look into your question in Github too, but as an quick answer there is ProductType already implemented and you can add your custom attributes to it.

Do you mean ProductType for defining set of attributes? No, it is not exactly what I mean. For me it's just looks like Shoop targeting on physical products only:
- required physical dimensions
- required sending address on order
- and so on...

I think it is maybe ok, but in that case every developer of digital shop will need to write a lot of customizations over it. Besides, plenty of other ecommerce solutions already have digital products integration by default, so some shop owners can set question like: "*Why do we need suggested by you Shoop, which will require so many customizations, if we can just go with magento?*".

html: @1905410 There already is minimal/"simple" digital product capabilities in the form of "shown-after-purchase" product media and nonphysical products.
text: @1905410 There already is minimal/"simple" digital product capabilities in the form of "shown-after-purchase" product media and nonphysical products.

html: @1905410 If you need more featureful digital license management for purchases, you could roll your own (since I'm not currently aware of the product roadmap for Shoop)
text: @1905410 If you need more featureful digital license management for purchases, you could roll your own (since I'm not currently aware of the product roadmap for Shoop)

html: @1905410 Admittedly there's lots of physical product features rolled into the default set of fields the Product models have. That's because the lineage of Shoop has been in shops mainly selling physical products... however, for shops mainly selling digital products, you can just ignore the physical dimensions fields, can't you? :) Or, if they bother you too much, you could patch in something that turns them into hidden fields.
text: @1905410 Admittedly there's lots of physical product features rolled into the default set of fields the Product models have. That's because the lineage of Shoop has been in shops mainly selling physical products... however, for shops mainly selling digital products, you can just ignore the physical dimensions fields, can't you? :) Or, if they bother you too much, you could patch in something that turns them into hidden fields.

html: As for "required sending address on order", if you mean the "policy" that the default checkout form requires the shipping address, that's fairly easy to change. The Order model itself, if I recall correctly, actually requires no addresses whatsoever.

html:
Yes, actually I have a question about that.

The AppliedAttribute model already has two models.TextField, so I see two ways of implementing multi-line attributes:

Option one

Add another two types into AttributeType model (e.g. translated_text_value and untranslated_text_value) and set up it just like an abstraction over already existing AppliedAttribute.untranslated_string_value and AppliedAttribute.translated_string_value fields.

So if user will try to set some_attribute.value like translated_text_value, then he will just fill up already existing AppliedAttribute.untranslated_string_value or AppliedAttribute.translated_string_value fields.

That way is fairly simple, but kind of ambiguous: some users may excpect to find in a database AppliedAttribute.translated_text_value or AppliedAttribute.untranslated_text_value, but they won't, because AttributeType.translated_text_value will be saved into AppliedAttribute.translated_string_value field.

Besides, I can't be sure about Shoop core interaction with the Attribute model. Is it possible that someone did worked directly with bare database fields from AppliedAttribute? I doubt that this is possible, but if it is, then this kind of abstraction won't work with that sort of code.

Option two

Besides two new attribute types, also add two fields into AppliedAttribute:

  • translated_text_value
  • untranslated_text_value

This way is more expected for end user, but from some perspective it require creating of unnecessary field on the model.

P.S. by "adding translated_text_value into AppliedAttribute" I mean concrete classes from base model.
text:
Yes, actually I have a question about that.

The ``AppliedAttribute`` model already has two ``models.TextField``, so I see two ways of implementing multi-line attributes:

#### Option one
Add another two types into ``AttributeType`` model (e.g. ``translated_text_value`` and ``untranslated_text_value``) and set up it just like an abstraction over already existing ``AppliedAttribute.untranslated_string_value`` and ``AppliedAttribute.translated_string_value`` fields.

So if user will try to set ``some_attribute.value`` like ``translated_text_value``, then he will just fill up already existing ``AppliedAttribute.untranslated_string_value`` or ``AppliedAttribute.translated_string_value`` fields.

That way is fairly simple, but kind of ambiguous: some users may excpect to find in a database ``AppliedAttribute.translated_text_value`` or ``AppliedAttribute.untranslated_text_value``, but they won't, because ``AttributeType.translated_text_value`` will be saved into ``AppliedAttribute.translated_string_value`` field.

Besides, I can't be sure about Shoop core interaction with the Attribute model. Is it possible that someone did worked directly with bare database fields from ``AppliedAttribute``? I doubt that this is possible, but if it is, then this kind of abstraction won't work with that sort of code.

#### Option two
Besides two new attribute types, also add two fields into ``AppliedAttribute``: 
- ``translated_text_value``
- ``untranslated_text_value``

This way is more expected for end user, but from some perspective it require creating of unnecessary field on the model.

P.S. by "*adding translated_text_value into ``AppliedAttribute``*" I mean concrete classes from base model.

html: @1905410 Since the *_string_value fields are already TextFields, nothing is preventing you from storing data that includes \n characters in them. It's just a matter of widget choice .
text: @1905410 Since the `*_string_value` fields are already TextFields, nothing is preventing you from storing data that includes `\n` characters in them. It's just a matter of widget choice .

html: So in order to implement multiline/rich text attributes, really all you need to do is make sure their editing widgets are forms.Textarea instead of forms.Input.
text: So in order to implement multiline/rich text attributes, really all you need to do is make sure their editing widgets are `forms.Textarea` instead of `forms.Input`.

html: Implementing multiline/rich text attributes should actually not require any database changes either. Sure, it will generate a migration as the AttributeType enum gets extended, but it will just be a "ceremonial" migration.
text: Implementing multiline/rich text attributes should actually not require any database changes either. Sure, it will generate a migration as the AttributeType enum gets extended, but it will just be a "ceremonial" migration.

html: As for the naming thing (option 1), I think it should be pretty clear for any developer that "string value" may mean any sort of text.
text: As for the naming thing (option 1), I think it should be pretty clear for any developer that "string value" may mean any sort of text.

html: Also, the primary interface for an end developer just interested in applied attributes' values should be the value property; that the data is stored in 3 different formats is an implementation detail that more concerns users who need to efficiently query the database based on certain attributes' values.
text: Also, the primary interface for an end developer just interested in applied attributes' values should be the `value` property; that the data is stored in 3 different formats is an implementation detail that more concerns users who need to efficiently query the database based on certain attributes' values.

        UNSTOCKED = _("unstocked")

In the end I decided to go away from Shoop attributes and create another custom addon. Still I'm curious... Don't you think that your attribute implementation is kind of strange? It's implementation looks like:

    Object
      ↓
      ↓
    Value  ← ←  Attribute

So if you need to get product attribute type in a template (for filter or whatever), you should write attribute.attribute.type =/ .
And what is more unclear to me: why Value(AppliedAttribute) is an abstract? Isn't this a nice case for django generic relations?
text:
In the end I decided to go away from Shoop attributes and create another custom addon. Still I'm curious... Don't you think that your attribute implementation is kind of strange? It's implementation looks like:
```
    Object
      ↓
      ↓
    Value  ← ←  Attribute
```
So if you need to get product attribute type in a template (for filter or whatever), you should write `attribute.attribute.type` =/ .
And what is more unclear to me: why `Value`(`AppliedAttribute`) is an `abstract`? Isn't this a nice case for django generic relations?

Hello everyone, I've changed some `settings.py` files for my store and when I run the `py.test` command several exceptions are thrown like this one:
```
___________________________________________________________________________________________ test_simple_supplier ____________________________________________________________________________________________

rf = <django.test.client.RequestFactory object at 0x7f5e9c1877b8>

    @pytest.mark.django_db
    def test_simple_supplier(rf):
        supplier = get_simple_supplier()
        shop = get_default_shop()
        product = create_product("simple-test-product", shop)
        ss = supplier.get_stock_status(product.pk)
        assert ss.product == product
        assert ss.logical_count == 0
        num = random.randint(100, 500)
        supplier.adjust_stock(product.pk, +num)
        assert supplier.get_stock_status(product.pk).logical_count == num
        # Create order ...
>       order = create_order_with_product(product, supplier, 10, 3, shop=shop)

html: @chessbr The shipping and payment method API will change in the Shoop's master branch quite soon though. The new API will use a concept called ServiceBehaviorComponent for defining behavior of a shipping or payment method. To implement the availability limiting functionality for your shipping method, you can just add a new behavior component for your shipping method and make that component override its is_available_for(service, source) method.
text: @chessbr The shipping and payment method API will change in the Shoop's master branch quite soon though. The new API will use a concept called ServiceBehaviorComponent for defining behavior of a shipping or payment method. To implement the availability limiting functionality for your shipping method, you can just add a new behavior component for your shipping method and make that component override its `is_available_for(service, source)` method.

text: @chessbr you should check the https://github.com/shoopio/shoop/blob/master/shoop/testing/models/_pseudo_payment.py as an example. html: For custom shipping method you need to create subclass from Carrier with your custom fields like API-keys and so on. Carrier should also define available services. Then for pricing, availability and shipping times you might need your own custom BehaviorComponents. There is also provide key service_behavior_component_form to enable your custom behavior components in admin. If you initialize all behaviors in create_service then the forms for behavior coponents might not be needed.
text: For custom shipping method you need to create subclass from ``Carrier`` with your custom fields like API-keys and so on. ``Carrier`` should also define available services. Then for pricing, availability and shipping times you might need your own custom ``BehaviorComponent``s. There is also provide key ``service_behavior_component_form`` to enable your custom behavior components in admin. If you initialize all behaviors in ``create_service`` then the forms for behavior coponents might not be needed.

html: @scopalaffairs It's really up to you how to link your business logic to Shoop products. The important thing to know here is that variations are just normal products in the end -- it's just that variation children aren't visible in usual frontend product selection, as selection is delegated to the variation parent. For your use case (if I remember it right), you'll just want to code up logic of your own to figure out which product to choose for your particular choice of options
text: @scopalaffairs It's really up to you how to link your business logic to Shoop products. The important thing to know here is that variations are just normal products in the end -- it's just that variation children aren't visible in usual frontend product selection, as selection is delegated to the variation parent. For your use case (if I remember it right), you'll just want to code up logic of your own to figure out which product to choose for your particular choice of options

html: Hey guys. Need some tips on hosting shoop as a multitenant app. Kind of what's going on at https://cloud.shoop.io
text: Hey guys. Need some tips on hosting shoop as a multitenant app. Kind of what's going on at https://cloud.shoop.io

html: Shoop Cloud isn't served by a single instance, but rather each shop is a separate Shoop installation.
text: Shoop Cloud isn't served by a single instance, but rather each shop is a separate Shoop installation.

html: Each have their own database and application process.
text: Each have their own database and application process.

html: Shoop also has the concept of Shops built in and then you could use single instance (within a single db) to serve several shops, but that would also mean that the shops share the product catalog. Also, that multi-shop feature is not yet very well tested and would need some extra development work too, since e.g. there is no middleware to set the correct shop by hostname or configuration as would be needed probably.
text: Shoop also has the concept of Shops built in and then you could use single instance (within a single db) to serve several shops, but that would also mean that the shops share the product catalog. Also, that multi-shop feature is not yet very well tested and would need some extra development work too, since e.g. there is no middleware to set the correct shop by hostname or configuration as would be needed probably.

html:
@devprodev Hi, looks like you might not have Shoop installed correctly. I'd suggest you the documentation on installing Shoop and see if you can get it working on your local development machine.
Once set up, you wouldn't run Shoop directly, but it would be installed as an app within a Django project.
shoop_workbench is the kind of "demo" project included to give you an example of how Shoop should be set up. Instructions on running shoop_workbench are included in the documentation as well.
Hope that helps! :smile:
text:
@devprodev Hi, looks like you might not have Shoop installed correctly. I'd suggest you the [documentation on installing Shoop](http://shoop.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started_dev.html) and see if you can get it working on your local development machine.
Once set up, you wouldn't run Shoop directly, but it would be installed as an app within a Django project.
shoop_workbench is the kind of "demo" project included to give you an example of how Shoop should be set up. Instructions on running shoop_workbench are included in the documentation as well.
Hope that helps! :smile:

html: hey @suutari-ai can I have your opinion about the payment process? I developed a payment integration with a credit card gateway.. the transaction logic is done inside get_payment_process_response method, here I send a request to the gateway and the response comes with the unique transactionID. I need to store this temporary to use it in process_payment_return_request. Some cards need customer authentication to approve the transaction and I need to redirect the user to a receivedd URL from the gateway response. After that, the gateway redirects the user to my return_urlwith no parameter (that is sad)! So I need that transactionID from somewhere.. I am currently saving it in order.payment_data. Don't you think that, in some cases, the access to the user session is a better way?
text: hey @suutari-ai can I have your opinion about the payment process? I developed a payment integration with a credit card gateway.. the transaction logic is done inside `get_payment_process_response` method, here I send a request to the gateway and the response comes with the unique transactionID. I need to store this temporary to use it in `process_payment_return_request `. Some cards need customer authentication to approve the transaction and I need to redirect the user to a receivedd URL from the gateway response. After that, the gateway redirects the user to my `return_url`with no parameter (that is sad)! So I need that transactionID from somewhere.. I am currently saving it in `order.payment_data`. Don't you think that, in some cases, the access to the user session is a better way?

html: @mrUmberto Not sure what you are trying to do, but you can always use payment_data in order to store some extra payment related information. Also you have option to extend Order with OneToOneField from your addon. Here is also an example about overring that method.

Also you have option to extend Order with OneToOneField from your addon. [Here](https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/03b5a975a3cd6868472ffd9b7c216b4412ec1758/shoop/testing/models/_pseudo_payment.py#L70) is also an example about overring that method.

html: anyone has a good advice on how to add blog features to shuup?
text: anyone has a good advice on how to add blog features to shuup?

html: Hi @farzeni shuup supports product bundles - after creating a product, go to edit->convert to package parent/variation parent. As for a blog, shuup has a fairly simple CMS bundled in. From admin, you can go to pages -> New Page. If you'd like to add your own blog, all you'll need to do is customize your theme to link to any blogging platform you like. Let us know if this handles your use case!
text: Hi @farzeni shuup supports product bundles - after creating a product, go to edit->convert to package parent/variation parent. As for a blog, shuup has a fairly simple CMS bundled in. From admin, you can go to pages -> New Page. If you'd like to add your own blog, all you'll need to do is customize your theme to link to any blogging platform you like. Let us know if this handles your use case!

html: @farzeni To expand on @gurch101's answering regarding adding blog features to Shuup, it should also be possible to use any existing Django-based CMS/blogging apps alongside Shuup since Shuup is basically just a collection of Django apps. This would be done as usual (including the apps in your project settings, etc).
text: @farzeni To expand on @gurch101's answering regarding adding blog features to Shuup, it should also be possible to use any existing Django-based CMS/blogging apps alongside Shuup since Shuup is basically just a collection of Django apps. html: Our sincerest apologies @dragonsg. We've been quite busy with the recent Shuup 0.4 release! Currently, our only public theme is classic grey which is bundled with Shuup. We are actively working on updating our demo sites and themes to work with the recent release of shuup - they are currently in flux but you can see them at demo1.shuup.com and demo2.shuup.com. We should also have additional themes available when we open our marketplace at the end of August. If there are any features in particular you are looking for or would like to build a new theme yourself, feel free to post any questions/comments here or on our forum: https://community.shuup.com/forums/
text: Our sincerest apologies @dragonsg. We've been quite busy with the recent Shuup 0.4 release! Currently, our only public theme is classic grey which is bundled with Shuup. Today's sales are based on orders that were completed today (ie orders that are fully paid and shipped)

text:

html:
Can someone please give me an advice about shuup addon system?

During my work with the shuup reviews addon I have encounter necessity to alter INSTALLED_APPS and REST_FRAMEWORK settings.

I need to add two new apps into INSTALLED_APPS. I did add to may addon AppConfig.required_installed_apps, but shuup doesn't alter INSTALLED_APPS and raises ImproperlyConfigured error. I suppose with some black magick I could alter INSTALLED_APPS at runtime, but is there any adequate way to do it?

I also can't find a way to alter REST_FRAMEWORK, because, as I can see, shuup doesn't allow to rewrite any _KNOWN_SETTINGS and raises ImproperlyConfigured error on attempt.
text:
Can someone please give me an advice about shuup addon system?

During my work with the shuup reviews addon I have encounter necessity to alter `INSTALLED_APPS` and `REST_FRAMEWORK` settings.

I need to add two new apps into `INSTALLED_APPS`. I did add to may addon `AppConfig.required_installed_apps`, but shuup doesn't alter `INSTALLED_APPS` and [raises](https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/e961373a5569f59c3df1cd5946ae99e735b86e0c/shuup/apps/__init__.py#L142) `ImproperlyConfigured` error. I suppose with some black magick I could alter `INSTALLED_APPS` at runtime, but is there any adequate way to do it?

I also can't find a way to alter `REST_FRAMEWORK`, because, as I can see, shuup doesn't allow to rewrite any `_KNOWN_SETTINGS` and [raises](https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/e961373a5569f59c3df1cd5946ae99e735b86e0c/shuup/apps/settings.py#L37) `ImproperlyConfigured` error on attempt.

html: @1905410 INSTALLED_APPS, and any other settings, should be modified in the django project's settings, not runtime.
text: @1905410 `INSTALLED_APPS`, and any other settings, should be modified in the django project's settings, not runtime.

html: @1905410 So basically, required_installed_apps is just a hint for the user of the addon/app to go edit their settings.
text: @1905410 So basically, `required_installed_apps` is just a hint for the user of the addon/app to go edit their settings.

html: Ah, I see, thanks for the answer. Would be really nice to see one day shuup providers system, that would add to enabled_addons file apps from required_installed_apps automatically.
text: Ah, I see, thanks for the answer. Would be really nice to see one day shuup providers system, that would add to `enabled_addons` file apps from `required_installed_apps` automatically.

html: The enabled_addons file was mostly designed to make it possible for the Cloud environment to be able to bootstrap itself. Anyway, there is a low-level API to manage the enabled_addons file... https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/addons/manager.py#L41

Hey guys, we have a problem. I have a product called Football which has a managed stock and the total stock is 2 (logical and physical). Then I created a package called Footballs Kit which is a package made of 2units of Football. Then I added the Footballs Kit inside the basket and also added a single unit of the Football, it means I am buying 3x Football and Shuup allows it! The stock is now -1!!
I was looking at the code and when I change the basket units, the BaseSupplierModule method get_orderability_errors(self, shop_product, quantity, customer) does not check the whole basket and maybe it is a problem because I can create several kinds of packages and each one can contains the same product.
text:
Hey guys, we have a problem. I have a product called **Football** which has a managed stock and the total stock is 2 (logical and physical). Then I created a package called **Footballs Kit** which is a package made of 2units of **Football**. Then I added the  **Footballs Kit** inside the basket and also added a single unit of the **Football**, it means I am buying 3x **Football** and Shuup allows it! The stock is now **-1**!!
I was looking at the code and when I change the basket units, the `BaseSupplierModule` method `get_orderability_errors(self, shop_product, quantity, customer)` does not check the whole basket and maybe it is a problem because I can create several kinds of packages and each one can contains the same product.

html: what do you think? How can we solve this? I can fix this but first, let me know what is your point and advice.

text:
@akx I am facing a terrible problem. I am in the middle of a gateway payment homologation and now I've tested Shuup on a production server with PostgreSQL. The problem is here:
```
# from shuup.core.models._orders
ip_address = models.GenericIPAddressField(null=True, blank=True, verbose_name=_('IP address')
```

html:
According to the https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/5622, it's a known issue and only affects psql databases:

I can confirm this issue exists with IPAddressField. The problem is that the both IPAddressField and GenericIPAddressField are backed by string types on most databases, but by INET on PostgreSQL. That explains why storing a blank value works with most databases, but breaks with PostgreSQL.
text:
According to the https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/5622, it's a known issue and only affects psql databases:
> I can confirm this issue exists with IPAddressField. The problem is that the both IPAddressField and GenericIPAddressField are backed by string types on most databases, but by INET on PostgreSQL. That explains why storing a blank value works with most databases, but breaks with PostgreSQL.

html:
shuup/core/order_creator/_source.py
def _get_products_and_quantities(self, supplier=None):
        q_counter = Counter()
        for line in self.get_lines():
            if not line.product:
                continue

            if supplier and line.supplier != supplier:
                continue

            package_children = line.product.get_package_child_to_quantity_map()
            for product, quantity in package_children.items():
                q_counter[product] += quantity

            product = line.product
            q_counter[product] += line.quantity

        return dict(q_counter)

I have published a working dev version of my product reviews plugin (actually already for a few weeks, just kept forgetting to write some installation instruction ._. ).

For a time I'm going to leave it like that and the next month I will probably spend mostly on the catalog filters plugin. But eventually I will get back to it and finish some last things (captcha for guest, better admin panel interface, etc).
text:
I have published a working dev version of my [product reviews plugin](https://gitlab.com/1905410/shuup-ucoms) (actually already for a few weeks, just kept forgetting to write some installation instruction ._. ).

For a time I'm going to leave it like that and the next month I will probably spend mostly on the catalog filters plugin. But eventually I will get back to it and finish some last things (captcha for guest, better admin panel interface, etc).

html: @chessbr I think the errors just should be handled and notified to end user. I believe admin side already does this. I think the source should be validated (source.get_validation_errors()) at shuup.front.checkout.confirn:ConfirmPhasebefore starting the order creator (maybe in ConfirmForm clean). I have added a bug task for us and these exceptions should be handled in the next version 0.4.5. Will inform you if that is not the case.
text: @chessbr I think the errors just should be handled and notified to end user. I believe admin side already does this. I think the source should be validated (`source.get_validation_errors()`) at `shuup.front.checkout.confirn:ConfirmPhase`before starting the order creator (maybe in `ConfirmForm` clean). I have added a bug task for us and these exceptions should be handled in the next version 0.4.5. Will inform you if that is not the case.

html: @hbakhtiyor Sure. The Russian is only 11% translated. https://www.transifex.com/shuup/shuup/ also we can setup custom domain for you in cloud. Contact devs@shuup.com directly to get that process rolling. No native mobile apps. The cloud is not free forever. Actually the next step would be that you will need to have sales every month to keep it free, for now it's only 1000$ of sales. Shuup is pretty young project we are now in version 0.4.5. Well cash on delivery would be some sort of manul payment method that you would set as paid when you get the cash. If your people is the ones doing the delivery then you would need a proper integration.

html: I need help, how to enable shuup as sub-site? like www.domain.com/store.  I got partial success by working on urls.py but still some ajax and other links still point to root, is there any central settings for it?
text: I need help, how to enable shuup as sub-site? like www.domain.com/store.  I got partial success by working on urls.py but still some ajax and other links still point to root, is there any central settings for it?

html:
@greenmughal If I understand your question correctly and you want to map /store to shuup, you shouldn't need to change any shuup code at all. This should be possible through your webserver config using aliases/rewrite rules. In nginx, you can do something like this:
location /store{
            include /etc/nginx/uwsgi_params;
            uwsgi_pass django;

            uwsgi_param Host $host;
            uwsgi_param X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
            uwsgi_param X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
            uwsgi_param X-Forwarded-Proto $http_x_forwarded_proto;
        }

html: @contactr2m Since Shuup is just a collection of django apps, you are free to use any cms you please - simply add it to your INSTALLED_APPS. You will likely need to change some storefront templates to show pages from wagtail. Shuup currently uses a fairly basic CMS that was built in-house - you will see it in the INSTALLED_APPS as shuup.simple_cms.
text: @contactr2m Since Shuup is just a collection of django apps, you are free to use any cms you please - simply add it to your `INSTALLED_APPS`.  You will likely need to change some storefront templates to show pages from wagtail. Shuup currently uses a fairly basic CMS that was built in-house - you will see it in the `INSTALLED_APPS` as `shuup.simple_cms`.

html:
I think I may stumble into some unexpected behavior of the product form in the admin panel. I wrote a test for it:

product_name_old = self.product.name
product_name_new = 'test_name'

form_gen = ShuupAdminProductEditFormGenerator(
    client=self.client,
    product_pk=self.product.pk,
)
form_gen.set_name(product_name_new)
form = form_gen.get_form()
response_weird = self.client.post(
    path=self.product_edit_url,
    data=form, follow=True,
)
self.assert_contains(response_weird, product_name_new, status_code=200)
# name was not updated
self.assert_equal(self.product.name, product_name_old)
self.assert_not_equal(self.product.name, product_name_new)

As you can see, response_weird contains product_name_new, but product.name was not actually updated.

Firstly I noticed that on my test server, but I thought that it was just some bug of my browser. Yet now when I can see the same behavior without any browser it really seems weird.

You may use my gitlab CI if you would like to recreate the scenario.

So, is this a bug or I am just missing something?
text:
I think I may stumble into some unexpected behavior of the product form in the admin panel. I wrote a [test](https://gitlab.com/nilit/shuup-helpers/blob/master/shuup_helpers/tests/test_generators/test_form_generator.py#L33) for it:
```python
product_name_old = self.product.name
product_name_new = 'test_name'

form_gen = ShuupAdminProductEditFormGenerator(
    client=self.client,
    product_pk=self.product.pk,
)
form_gen.set_name(product_name_new)
form = form_gen.get_form()
response_weird = self.client.post(
    path=self.product_edit_url,
    data=form, follow=True,
)
self.assert_contains(response_weird, product_name_new, status_code=200)
# name was not updated
self.assert_equal(self.product.name, product_name_old)
self.assert_not_equal(self.product.name, product_name_new)
```
As you can see, `response_weird` contains `product_name_new`, but `product.name` was not actually updated.

Firstly I noticed that on my test server, but I thought that it was just some bug of my browser. Yet now when I can see the same behavior without any browser it really seems weird.

You may use my [gitlab CI](https://gitlab.com/nilit/shuup-helpers/blob/master/.gitlab-ci.yml) if you would like to recreate the scenario.

So, is this a bug or I am just missing something?

html:
sure, thanks Christian :)

FROM node:6.9.4

COPY . /shuup/app

RUN apt-get update && \
    apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends python3-minimal python3-virtualenv python3-pip python3-dev python3-pil \
    vim curl && \
    apt-get clean && \
    rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*
RUN echo '{ "allow_root": true }' > /root/.bowerrc
RUN python3 -m virtualenv -p /usr/bin/python3 --system-site-packages /shuup/venv && \
    /shuup/venv/bin/pip install -U pip setuptools
RUN cd /shuup/app && /shuup/venv/bin/pip install -e .
RUN /shuup/venv/bin/python -m shuup_workbench migrate
RUN /shuup/venv/bin/python -m shuup_workbench shuup_populate_mock --with-superuser=admin

And then I run 

/bin/sh /shuup/app/container-app/bootstrap_dev.sh

from the docker compose which does

cd /shuup/app
/shuup/venv/bin/python -m shuup_workbench runserver 0.0.0.0:8000
text:
sure, thanks Christian :)
```
FROM node:6.9.4

COPY . /shuup/app

RUN apt-get update && \
    apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends python3-minimal python3-virtualenv python3-pip python3-dev python3-pil \
    vim curl && \
    apt-get clean && \
    rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*
RUN echo '{ "allow_root": true }' > /root/.bowerrc
RUN python3 -m virtualenv -p /usr/bin/python3 --system-site-packages /shuup/venv && \
    /shuup/venv/bin/pip install -U pip setuptools
RUN cd /shuup/app && /shuup/venv/bin/pip install -e .
RUN /shuup/venv/bin/python -m shuup_workbench migrate
RUN /shuup/venv/bin/python -m shuup_workbench shuup_populate_mock --with-superuser=admin
```

And then I run 
```
/bin/sh /shuup/app/container-app/bootstrap_dev.sh
```
from the docker compose which does

```
cd /shuup/app
/shuup/venv/bin/python -m shuup_workbench runserver 0.0.0.0:8000
```

html: @chessbr Thanks for the reply. So, in the meantime what's the best what to approach this. How can I as a super admin of the site go about setting up, and approving shops? Any guidance would be apprecaited. Thanks
text: @chessbr Thanks for the reply. So, in the meantime what's the best what to approach this. How can I as a super admin of the site go about setting up, and approving shops? Any guidance would be apprecaited. Thanks

html: @aoy12 You can directly create the Shop through Shop.objects.create(), you will see it and can configure it on the Shuup admin, however, the you will have to write some code do distinguish shops in front, since we are using always the first one. Also admin will need to have some changes. Shuup has a solid base for this feature, but to enable multi-shop would require a customized project. Also, the business logic of the desired shop would set requirements for the amount of customization work needed to enable it. We will be adding functionality around this multi-shop feature, so that implementing these kinds of shops will be easier.
text: @aoy12 You can directly create the Shop through `Shop.objects.create()`, you will see it and can configure it on the Shuup admin, however, the you will have to write some code do distinguish shops in front, since we are using always the first one. Also admin will need to have some changes. Shuup has a solid base for this feature, but to enable multi-shop would require a customized project. Also, the business logic of the desired shop would set requirements for the amount of customization work needed to enable it. We will be adding functionality around this multi-shop feature, so that implementing these kinds of shops will be easier.

html:
Hey, how are the user/contact relation ship supposed to be used? Tried looking up it on the documentation with not much success. In my service I create orders through the api and manage users on my own. Looks like order creation asks for a customer which in turn is a contact which in turn may or may not be linked to an actual user object.

I have a requirement to later on query for orders of a specific user (in my service). Apparently I cannot just query for orders by contact or user. Issue here is that these contacts seem to be fairly weakly unique. There seems not be any unique fields for me to query with.

tldr; I'm trying to define a flow of a user ordering... 1) Get or create new customer in shuup 2) create order for that user 3) query for this specific users orders
text:
Hey, how are the user/contact relation ship supposed to be used? Tried looking up it on the documentation with not much success. In my service I create orders through the api and manage users on my own. Looks like order creation asks for a customer which in turn is a contact which in turn may or may not be linked to an actual user object.

I have a requirement to later on query for orders of a specific user (in my service). Apparently I cannot just query for orders by contact or user. Issue here is that these contacts seem to be fairly weakly unique. There seems not be any unique fields for me to query with.

tldr; I'm trying to define a flow of a user ordering... 1) Get or create new customer in shuup 2) create order for that user 3) query for this specific users orders

html: PersonContact has the user FK
text: `PersonContact` has the `user` FK

html: https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/core/models/_contacts.py#L285
text: https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/core/models/_contacts.py#L285

html: It is not necessary required, but if you want, it can be associated with a single user
text: It is not necessary required, but if you want, it can be associated with a single user

text: If let's say, I'd like to skip creating an actual user and working with just contacts, should I then persist the contact id myself since contact fields aren't at all unique

html: yes, you can use the identifier field to help you https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/core/models/_contacts.py#L97 but check if the field match you requirements
text: yes, you can use the `identifier` field to help you https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/core/models/_contacts.py#L97 but check if the field match you requirements

html:
ok, seem that the serializer is explicitly excluding the identifier field. wondering why.. but ok, you will need to extend the API. first you need to add a custom API endpoint that points to to a ViewSet that extends the ContactViewSet. Then you set a custom serializer. that serializer will extend the ContactSerializer and just remove the identifier from the fields attributes, something like this:
class CustomPersonContactSerializer(PersonContactSerializer):
    class Meta(PersonContactSerializer.Meta):
        fields = []

class CustomPersonContactViewSet(PersonContactViewSet):
    serializer_class = CustomPersonContactSerializer
you will have to create an api_populator entry into your app provides, and in the api populator you do: router.register("CUSTOM/contact", CustomPersonContactViewSet)
text: you will have to create an `api_populator` entry into your app provides, and in the api populator you do: `router.register("CUSTOM/contact", CustomPersonContactViewSet)`

html: Alright, if anyone's intrested as my services flow requires passing through orders without billing or shipping address, as they are given later in the payment phase if necessary, I went ahead and extended the OrderViewSet with my own create method which instead used my own JsonOrderCreator which overrided the _get_address function to return None if the passed in address was gibberish. This way everything looks like they work as they should.

html: Hi Experts, in the context of Manual / Custom Payment methods (we have an Invoice method where customers have Net 30), it seems Shuup doesn't consider an order a Sales Order until a payment is made.    This means all the reports, Dashboards, etc will not recognize the order.    Did we do something wrong, or what is the best way to override the SalesOrder definition?
text: Hi Experts, in the context of Manual / Custom Payment methods (we have an Invoice method where customers have Net 30), it seems Shuup doesn't consider an order a Sales Order until a payment is made.    This means all the reports, Dashboards, etc will not recognize the order.    Did we do something wrong, or what is the best way to override the SalesOrder definition?

html: Well most of the reports and dashboard are about completed orders. And complete usually means paid and shipped. In Shuup Order-model we define whether order can be set complete like thisreturn not (self.is_complete() or self.is_canceled() or bool(self.get_unshipped_products())). If you need to set order complete "automatically" then you need to add some custom logic to do it. Customizing that invoice payment method would be choice here. Other option would be to write some script which just sets orders with that payment method completed.
text: Well most of the reports and dashboard are about completed orders. And complete usually means paid and shipped. In Shuup Order-model we define whether order can be set complete  like this`return not (self.is_complete() or self.is_canceled() or bool(self.get_unshipped_products()))`. If you need to set order complete "automatically" then you need to add some custom logic to do it. Customizing that invoice payment method would be choice here. Other option would be  to write some script which just sets  orders with that payment method completed.

html: Hi, everyone. How can I translate shuup by transifex.com files? I have a for_useshuup<appications_names>_ru.po files, I put it in the applications folders, called compilemessages, called makemessages and.... nothing happened. How can I use *.po files of transifex.com?
text: Hi, everyone. How can I translate shuup by transifex.com files? I have a for_use_shuup_<appications_names>_ru.po files, I put it in the applications folders, called compilemessages, called makemessages and.... nothing happened. How can I use *.po files of transifex.com?

html: @DrMartiner Hi Alex, have you tried to use the Transifex client to download the translations? you can use the command tx pull -fl ru to download only the RU translations files and after that just run python setup.py build_messages to compile them. You will probably need an API token to use the Transifex client (https://docs.transifex.com/client/client-configuration) and of course, do not forget to add the RU language on your settings, LANGUAGES list.
text: @DrMartiner Hi Alex, have you tried to use the Transifex client to download the translations? you can use the command `tx pull -fl ru` to download only the RU translations files and after that just run `python setup.py build_messages` to compile them. You will probably need an API token to use the Transifex client (https://docs.transifex.com/client/client-configuration) and of course, do not forget to add the RU language on your settings, `LANGUAGES` list.

from shuup.core.utils.forms import MutableAddressForm

class AddressCustomForm(MutableAddressForm):
def init(self, args, **kwargs):
super(AddressCustomForm, self).init(args, **kwargs)
self.fields.pop('street2')

self.fields['email'].required = True
self.fields['postal_code'].required = True
text:
from shuup.core.utils.forms import MutableAddressForm


class AddressCustomForm(MutableAddressForm):
    def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
        super(AddressCustomForm, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs)
        self.fields.pop('street2')
        self.fields.pop('region_code')
        self.fields['email'].required = True
        self.fields['postal_code'].required = True

from django.shortcuts import render
from shuup.front.checkout.addresses import AddressesPhase
from shuup.apps.custom_checkout.forms import AddressCustomForm

class ShippingPhaseAddress(AddressesPhase):
address_kinds = ("shipping",)
address_form_classes = {"shipping":AddressCustomForm}
company_form_class = {}

def __init__(self,  **kwargs):
    super(ShippingPhaseAddress, self).__init__(**kwargs)
@soulilya You can just define SHUUP_ADDRESS_MODEL_FORM = "your_custom_address_form" in your project settings to override the address phase form.
text: @soulilya You can just define `SHUUP_ADDRESS_MODEL_FORM = "your_custom_address_form"` in your project settings to override the address phase form.

html: Correct first you need custom shipping component which requests the shipping costs. For this there is an example here https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/testing/models/_behavior_components.py#L14. After this you want to provide front_service_checkout_phase_provider from your app. Here is few examples for custom checkout phase for payment or shipping methods.
text: Correct first you need custom shipping component which requests the shipping costs. For this there is an example here https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/testing/models/_behavior_components.py#L14. After this you want  to provide `front_service_checkout_phase_provider` from your app. Here  is few examples for custom checkout phase for payment or shipping methods.

html: If your only goal is to get custom price for your shipping then you already should have everything in order source or basket when getting the shipping costs in your custom behavior component.
text: If your only goal is to get custom price for your shipping then you already should have everything in order source or basket when getting the shipping costs in your custom behavior component.

html: The custom checkout phase usually is something extra for the selected shipping method. Like selecting pickup point in case the carrier allows multiple choices. @soulilya
text: The custom checkout phase usually is something extra for the selected shipping method. Like selecting pickup point in case the carrier allows multiple choices. @soulilya

html: After ordering if you need to print labels or such for your carrier. Then customizing the admin view for your shipment creation can be useful.
text: After ordering if you need to print labels or such for your carrier. Then customizing the admin view for your shipment creation can be useful.

text: Yes shipment is created after the order is received by merchant (not in checkout). For basic implementation login to admin and go to order. When the order is paid there is option to create shipment. This way you can how that is handled.

html: If you want to create shipment automatically when the order is received. Then you could catch the order or payment created signal and then just call order.create_shipment with the shipped products.
text: If you want to create shipment automatically when the order is received. Then you could  catch the order or payment created signal and then just call `order.create_shipment` with the shipped products.

text:
yeah I got it.. try using this:
```py

from django.utils.translation import ugettext_lazy as _

from shuup.admin.base import AdminModule, MenuEntry
from shuup.admin.utils.permissions import get_default_model_permissions
from shuup.core.models import ShippingMethod

class MyCustomShippingModule(AdminModule):
    name = _("Custom Shipping Module")

    def get_urls(self):
        return [
            admin_url(
                "^shipping_service/(?P<pk>\d+)/create-shipping-order/$",
                "shuup.apps.shipping_service.views.CreateShippingOrder",
                name="shipping_service.create-shipping-order",
                permissions=get_default_model_permissions(ShippingMethod),
            )
        ]

    def get_required_permissions(self):
        return get_default_model_permissions(ShippingMethod)
```
then add it to the provides:
```py
'admin_module': [
    'your_app_path.MyCustomShippingModule'
]
```

html: Is the multi-vendor feature available in the open source version of shuup?
text: Is the multi-vendor feature available in the open source version of shuup?

html: Yes. But it doesn’t cover all possible scenarios. For now it is based on shops. So can introduce multiple shops/vendors which all have their own shop and shop products. Then you assign each shop their own front. Or build your own marketplace type front. With this the limitation is that the basket is per shop.
text: Yes. But it doesn’t cover all possible scenarios. For now it is based on shops. So can introduce multiple shops/vendors which all have their own shop and shop products. Then you assign each shop their own front. Or build your own marketplace type front. With this the limitation is that the basket is per shop.

html: Other option would be to customize a little and use Shuup suppliers as vendors. This way you can notify each supplier based on the order lines. The main shop would receive the ordes and payments. This would require small customized admin view for vendors to manage products they supply for the marketplace.
text: Other option would be to customize a little and use Shuup suppliers as vendors. This way you can notify each supplier based on the order lines. The main shop would receive the ordes and payments. This would require small customized admin view for vendors to manage products they supply for the marketplace.

html:
if so, keep it in mind that an order can have more than one shipment. that said, to add a custom column there, you have to customize the order admin list. https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/admin/modules/orders/views/list.py#L45
Basically, you have to remove the original OrderModule from the provides and add your custom one, this can be done using the brand new setting https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/doc/ref/provides.rst#blacklisting-provides and then write your admin module, something like this

class CustomOrderModule(OrderModule):
    def get_urls(self):
        return [
          admin_url(
                "^orders/$",
                "my_custom_orders_module.views.MyOrderListView",
                name="order.list",
                permissions=get_default_model_permissions(Order),
            ),
        ] + super().get_urls()

Then in your MyOrderListView add the column you want and add CustomOrderModule to your admin_module provides
text:
if so, keep it in mind that an order can have more than one shipment. that said, to add a custom column there, you have to customize the order admin list. https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/admin/modules/orders/views/list.py#L45
Basically, you have to remove the original `OrderModule` from the provides and add your custom one, this can be done using the brand new setting https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/doc/ref/provides.rst#blacklisting-provides and then write your admin module, something like this
```py
class CustomOrderModule(OrderModule):
    def get_urls(self):
        return [
          admin_url(
                "^orders/$",
                "my_custom_orders_module.views.MyOrderListView",
                name="order.list",
                permissions=get_default_model_permissions(Order),
            ),
        ] + super().get_urls()
```
Then in your `MyOrderListView` add the column you want and add `CustomOrderModule` to your `admin_module` provides

you can change the OrderListView.get_queryset to filter more and more the Order model, but I guess that is not what you are trying to do right? You want related fields for each line of the list. So basically you can add a new column like this:

Column("my_custom_column_name", _(u"My Custom Column"), display="get_my_custom_column"),

once you did this, the display arg can be a function on the OrderListView to return the column value like this:

class OrderCustomList(OrderListView):
    default_columns = OrderListView.default_comuns + [
          Column("my_custom_column_name", _(u"My Custom Column"), display="get_my_custom_column"),
     ]
    def get_my_custom_column(self, instance, *args, **kwargs):
         # here instance is the model instance returned by the get_queryset, in this case an Order
         return instance.shipments.filter(x=1).first().name
text:
you can change the `OrderListView.get_queryset` to filter more and more the Order model, but I guess that is not what you are trying to do right? You want related fields for each line of the list. So basically you can add a new column like this:
```py
Column("my_custom_column_name", _(u"My Custom Column"), display="get_my_custom_column"),
```
once you did this, the `display` arg can be a function on the `OrderListView` to return the column value like this:
```py
class OrderCustomList(OrderListView):
    default_columns = OrderListView.default_comuns + [
          Column("my_custom_column_name", _(u"My Custom Column"), display="get_my_custom_column"),
     ]
    def get_my_custom_column(self, instance, *args, **kwargs):
         # here instance is the model instance returned by the get_queryset, in this case an Order
         return instance.shipments.filter(x=1).first().name
```

html: Hallo! I already mentioned that our company wants 4 more shops on base shuup. So is possible manage several shops on one database ? I mean, other settings, other themes, order and product management per shop? If yes, how to do that?
text: Hallo! I already mentioned that our company wants 4 more shops on base shuup. So is possible manage several shops on one database ? I mean, other settings, other themes, order and product management per shop? If yes, how to do that?

html: @soulilya It is possible, yes, but partially. You can check some issues here: shuup/shuup#1275 So, at this very moment, it is possible to create multi shops in same database, but they shouldn't be able to configure there own order status, product types and other models that don't have shop as an attribute. Without that, all shops have access to the same objects and that could lead to some issues (battling for changing them). So, depending on your project requirements, I recommend you to check all models that don't have the shop and check if that is required to be per-shop object, if so, you have to create a new database for each shop. Now, creating a new DB for each new shop will require you to have new settings and probably new http server workers.
text: @soulilya It is possible, yes, but partially. You can check some issues here: https://github.com/shuup/shuup/issues/1275 So, at this very moment, it is possible to create multi shops in same database, but they shouldn't be able to configure there own order status, product types and other models that don't have `shop` as an attribute. Without that, all shops have access to the same objects and that could lead to some issues (battling for changing them). So, depending on your project requirements, I recommend you to check all models that don't have the `shop` and check if that is required to be per-shop object, if so, you have to create a new database for each shop. Now, creating a new DB for each new shop will require you to have new settings and probably new http server workers.

html: basically, the provides load functions and classes dynamically and invoke/instantiate them.
text: basically, the provides load functions and classes dynamically and invoke/instantiate them.

html:
let's say you have a custom admin module view, and there is some calculations to do, but you don't want to write your calculator, you want others to provide some way of calculation, then you can create a provide key and expect others to write the calculator:
def calculate_the_solution(self, x, b):
    calculators = get_provide_objects("my_calculator_key")
    for calculator in calculators:
          if calculator.knows_how_to_calculate(a, b):
             return calculator.calculate(a, b)
    # no provides added or no calculator know how to calculate
   return None

so you or any other can write a calculator and put the class in the apps.py provides using your key:

your implementation

class MyCalculator(object):
    @classmethod
    def knows_how_to_calculate(cls, a, b):
         return True
    @classmethod
     def calculate(cls, a, b):
          return a+b

the apps.py

class MyAppConfig(shuup.apps.AppConfig):
     provides = {
            "my_calculator_key": [
                   "my_app.MyCalculator",
                   "other_app.Calculator"
            ]
    }

html:
Well how we see it is that with provides there are a lot of good benefits compared to typical "overloading things". One would be that it keeps things modular and for example the admin app doesn't need to know anything about all the different addons that extends it. It's just addons responsibility to provide some admin module or formpart in case it needs to be configured.

But yeah keep the feedback coming and if you are working on Shuup more you have always chance to contribute and make it better.
text:
Well how we see it is that with provides there are a lot of good benefits compared to typical "overloading things". One would be that it keeps things modular and for example the admin app doesn't need to know anything about all the different addons that extends it. It's just addons responsibility to provide some admin module or formpart in case it needs to be configured.

But yeah keep the feedback coming and if you are working on Shuup more you have always chance to contribute and make it better.

class PageBaseFormPart(FormPart):
priority = 1
def get_form_defs(self):
    yield TemplatedFormDef(
        "base",
        PageForm,
        template_name="shuup/simple_cms/admin/_edit_base_page_form.jinja",
        required=True,
        kwargs={
            "instance": self.object,
            "languages": settings.LANGUAGES,
            "request": self.request
        }
    )

def form_valid(self, form):
    self.object = form["base"].save()

html:
class PageEditView(SaveFormPartsMixin, FormPartsViewMixin, CreateOrUpdateView):
model = Page
template_name = "shuup/simple_cms/admin/edit.jinja"
base_form_part_classes = [PageBaseFormPart,]
context_object_name = "page"
form_part_class_provide_key = "admin_page_form_part"
add_form_errors_as_messages = True
def save_form(self, form):
    self.object = form.save()
    if not self.object.created_by:
        self.object.created_by = self.request.user
    self.object.modified_by = self.request.user
    self.object.save()

def get_queryset(self):
    return super(PageEditView, self).get_queryset()\
                                    .for_shop(get_shop(self.request))\
                                    .filter(deleted=False)

def get_toolbar(self):
    save_form_id = self.get_save_form_id()
    if save_form_id:
        return get_default_edit_toolbar(self, save_form_id)

@atomic
def form_valid(self, form):
    return self.save_form_parts(form)

html:
as that is used in some places, you can change Shuup to load this function from a SETTING.
something like:

def model_url(context, model, absolute=False):
       model_url_resolver = cached_load("SHUUP_MODEL_URL_RESOLVER_SPEC")
       return model_url_resolver(context, model, absolute)

then you put the Shuup original model_url in other file and make that model url resolver as the default

shuup/front/utils/urls.py

def model_url(context, model, absolute=False):
    uri = None
    if isinstance(model, Product):
        uri = reverse("shuup:product", kwargs=dict(pk=model.pk, slug=model.slug))
   [...]

and add this config to the settings

SHUUP_MODEL_URL_RESOLVER_SPEC = "shuup.front.utils.urls.model_url"

if you want to create that and submit the PR we will be happy to review and merge :)
text:
as that is used in some places, you can change Shuup to load this function from a SETTING.
something like:
```py
def model_url(context, model, absolute=False):
       model_url_resolver = cached_load("SHUUP_MODEL_URL_RESOLVER_SPEC")
       return model_url_resolver(context, model, absolute)
```

then you put the Shuup original `model_url` in other file and make that model url resolver as the default

`shuup/front/utils/urls.py`
```py
def model_url(context, model, absolute=False):
    uri = None
    if isinstance(model, Product):
        uri = reverse("shuup:product", kwargs=dict(pk=model.pk, slug=model.slug))
   [...]
```
and add this config to the settings
```py
SHUUP_MODEL_URL_RESOLVER_SPEC = "shuup.front.utils.urls.model_url"
```

if you want to create that and submit the PR we will be happy to review and merge :)

html: @AjjuSingh Hi! What do you mean? :P

html: @soulilya Hi! No problems at all, we just like to compile static sources because of some reasons: transpile JS and make sure it works on all browsers, bundle all code into a single file and minify it (both css and js) and use LESS or SCSS to style the site.. so if you release the static css I can't see any issue if you are 100% your are not missing rules for all major browsers, which autoprefixer does automatically for us when compiling =)
text: @soulilya Hi! No problems at all, we just like to compile static sources because of some reasons: transpile JS and make sure it works on all browsers, bundle all code into a single file and minify it (both css and js) and use LESS or SCSS to style the site.. so if you release the static css I can't see any issue if you are 100% your are not missing rules for all major browsers, which autoprefixer does automatically for us when compiling =)

html: We're testing a multitenant setup and are having trouble figuring out how to create a shop admin account that isn't a superuser.  Right now, the only way we can find to create an admin for a shop grants them access to all shops.
text: We're testing a multitenant setup and are having trouble figuring out how to create a shop admin account that isn't a superuser.  Right now, the only way we can find to create an admin for a shop grants them access to all shops.

html: Is that something the framework supports or do we need to hand roll that?
text: Is that something the framework supports or do we need to hand roll that?

html:
@Juli4nAc0sta_gitlab unfortunately, no. we don't have this feature yet. But you can achieve that "easily" writing a custom Pricing Module. We use this as the default: https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/core/pricing/default_pricing.py#L14
Basically what you have to do is create some dropdown to select the current currency and then use this as the context in your price module. You will need some conversion table from your base price to some other currency or create some price config for each product, which is not good for merchant :)

Basically what you have to do is create some dropdown to select the current currency and then use this as the context in your price module. You will need some conversion table from your base price to some other currency or create some price config for each product, which is not good for merchant :)

html:
it is possible to configure permission groups for staff users so they can only access shop admin for certain shops.. you must add them to the shop staff member list.. you will also need to enable multishop environment through settings..
the question is, what kind of solution are you looking for? Shuup can be anything you want, but you probably need to create some small modules to make it fit your needs.
Are you after a marketplace like Amazon which has multiple vendors and only a single shop or a multishop env where you can have N shops that can be accessed through different domains?

html: @jhubsharp Permission groups is only used for staff users to use in admin. If you want to create something similar to front users, you could try using contact groups and some utils to use with that. I will ask @tulimaki if he has other idea. Maybe you can also create custom django user permissions in your addon through migration file (check how we did to create a custom permission for user to access admin: https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/admin/migrations/0001_initial.py#L12), then you can just use user.has_perm("my_custom_perm_identifier"), the Django way. Of course this would require some custom admin page to configure which permissions for contact group users should have etc..
text: @jhubsharp Permission groups is only used for staff users to use in admin.
