Of course this would require some custom admin page to configure which permissions for contact group users should have etc..

html: Thanks. We discussed using contact groups but I don't really like that solution since it's at the contact level and it seems to break SRP on what those should be used for. We may see if this is something where we can lock down the bulk of items in SA and give these users SA access to a limited set of functionality. Otherwise we'll explore that custom permission.
text: Thanks. We discussed using contact groups but I don't really like that solution since it's at the contact level and it seems to break SRP on what those should be used for. We may see if this is something where we can lock down the bulk of items in SA and give these users SA access to a limited set of functionality. Otherwise we'll explore that custom permission.

html:
@jhubsharp For the permissions you should most of the time use permission groups which are linked to Django users. You are correct Shuup uses this only in admin for admin module permissions. I think using contact groups is something that is not meant to be for permissions but surely possible.

For shuup.front we now have the xtheme placeholders to show different content for different contact groups and it is easy to add a different kind of logic for showing placeholders (like here for example https://github.com/shuup/shuup-xtheme-extra-layouts). But I doubt this is what you are after.

For storefront, you can use permissions groups to group users as well. For front views, you have to add permission logic by yourself. And this could be achieved for example this way https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/topics/auth/default/#the-permissionrequiredmixin-mixin or with decorator like https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/topics/auth/default/#django.contrib.auth.decorators.user_passes_test. For templates whether to show some link to view or not you can probably implement some template helper to check these custom permissions of yours.

And like Christian mentioned above. You have also option to create custom Django permissions which can be linked to permission groups if needed.
text:
@jhubsharp For the permissions you should most of the time use permission groups which are linked to Django users. You are correct Shuup uses this only in admin for admin module permissions. I think using contact groups is something that is not meant to be for permissions but surely possible.

For `shuup.front` we now have the xtheme placeholders to show different content for different contact groups and it is easy to add a different kind of logic for showing placeholders (like here for example https://github.com/shuup/shuup-xtheme-extra-layouts). But I doubt this is what you are after.

For storefront, you can use permissions groups to group users as well. For front views, you have to add permission logic by yourself. And this could be achieved for example this way https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/topics/auth/default/#the-permissionrequiredmixin-mixin or with decorator like https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/topics/auth/default/#django.contrib.auth.decorators.user_passes_test. For templates whether to show some link to view or not you can probably implement some template helper to check these custom permissions of yours.

And like Christian mentioned above. You have also option to create custom Django permissions which can be linked to permission groups if needed.

html: If you for some reason need to add these permission checks for existing Shuup views in front I would probably just wrap these decorators to URLs directly and do something else than this https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup_workbench/urls.py#L14 at the project URLs. This way you don’t necessarily need customized Shuup version to achieve these custom permission for Shuup views.
text: If you for some reason need to add these permission checks for existing Shuup views in front I would probably just wrap these decorators to URLs directly and do something else than this https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup_workbench/urls.py#L14 at the project URLs. This way you don’t necessarily need customized Shuup version to achieve these custom permission for Shuup views.

html: Hey, guys. Trying to figure out the provides system. What's the best way to add a field to an existing form in the admin? For example, what's the best way to add a field to the products basic information form?
text: Hey, guys. Trying to figure out the provides system. What's the best way to add a field to an existing form in the admin? For example, what's the best way to add a field to the products basic information form?

html: @aFraley you can’t create new fields to the “product basic information” since that is it’s own Django form. What you can do is to create form part which adds new “tab” to product edit-view. In this form part you can have any field you need for your custom implementations. You can find example here: https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/customer_group_pricing/__init__.py#L25.
text: @aFraley you can’t create new fields to the “product basic information” since that is it’s own Django form. What you can do is to create form part which adds new “tab” to product edit-view. In this form part you can have any field you need for your custom implementations. You can find example here: https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/customer_group_pricing/__init__.py#L25.

html: If you feel that the product admin module should be completely something else than what we have in Shuup you can create your own and provide it from your addon or app. After this you can either blackilist the default admin module or tune your shop staff permissions so that the default product admin module is not visible. About provides and blacklisting them per project check this https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/doc/ref/provides.rst. @aFraley

html:
hi @armanlearn welcome! The concept of vendor depends on what you are after, a marketplace or a multishop environment. both are supported with Shuup platform.
For multishop env where you can have multiple domains and each one of them is a completely different shop, you just have to change some core Shuup settings to enable that and create multiple shops in admin and attach staff members to it. Now a marketplace can be achieved by creating multiple Suppliers (vendors). This feature is not ready out of the box and needs some custom modules to make that work according to your project needs.
text:
hi @armanlearn welcome! The concept of vendor depends on what you are after, a marketplace or a multishop environment. both are supported with Shuup platform.
For multishop env where you can have multiple domains and each one of them is a completely different shop, you just have to change some core Shuup settings to enable that and create multiple shops in admin and attach staff members to it. Now a marketplace can be achieved by creating multiple Suppliers (vendors). This feature is not ready out of the box and needs some custom modules to make that work according to your project needs.

html:
hi @tulimaki @chessbr I gave-up with sqlite3, I used version 3.24.0 and still got the same error, what I did was to set-up a postgresql server by adding into the setup.py the 'psycopg2>=2.7.6' dependecy which probably can be changed by psycopg2-binary, also add the DATABASES configuration as the following:

DATABASES = {
    'default': {
        'ENGINE': 'django.db.backends.postgresql',
        'NAME': 'dbname',
        'USER': 'user',
        'PASSWORD': '',
        'HOST': '127.0.0.1',
        'PORT': '5432',
    }
}

and works fine, just in case that can be an improvement on the project, thanks both for the support checking that and letting me know that was a database issue :)
text:
hi @tulimaki @chessbr I gave-up with sqlite3, I used version 3.24.0 and still got the same error, what I did was to set-up a postgresql server by adding into the `setup.py` the `'psycopg2>=2.7.6'` dependecy which probably can be changed by `psycopg2-binary`, also add the DATABASES configuration as the following:
```
DATABASES = {
    'default': {
        'ENGINE': 'django.db.backends.postgresql',
        'NAME': 'dbname',
        'USER': 'user',
        'PASSWORD': '',
        'HOST': '127.0.0.1',
        'PORT': '5432',
    }
}
```
and works fine, just in case that can be an improvement on the project, thanks both for the support checking that and letting me know that was a database issue :)

html: @saikiruba.mj_gitlab this is how shop for front is defined here https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/core/shop_provider.py. You can change this logic with Djagno setting defined here https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/core/settings.py#L241. Locally you can make the shops change by defining your shop domain and tweaking your local hosts file (or just tune that shop provider class).
text: @saikiruba.mj_gitlab this is how shop for front is defined here https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/core/shop_provider.py. You can change this logic with Djagno setting defined here https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/core/settings.py#L241. Locally you can make the shops change by defining your shop domain and tweaking your local hosts file (or just tune that shop provider class).

html: For admin panel Shuup uses different logic since some staff might have access to multiple shops. Shuup uses this https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/admin/shop_provider.py when figuring out which Shop to use in Admin.
text: For admin panel Shuup uses different logic since some staff might have access to multiple shops. Shuup uses this https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/admin/shop_provider.py when figuring out which Shop to use in Admin.

I'm trying to understand Tax Rules. We have some Products which are Taxful (8.25%) and some Tax-exempt (0%). We have set Tax Classes on the Products (along with Taxes and Tax Rules)... This works fine.

We now have some Customers that are completely Tax Exempt on everything. I've tried to create a Customer Tax Group and then a new Tax Rule to show 0% .. but it seems the Product Tax Class is still over-riding, even if I change Priority on both. Any ideas?
text:
I'm trying to understand Tax Rules.  We have some Products which are Taxful (8.25%) and some Tax-exempt (0%).  We have set Tax Classes on the Products (along with Taxes and Tax Rules)... This works fine.

We now have some Customers that are completely Tax Exempt on everything.   I've tried to create a Customer Tax Group and then a new Tax Rule to show 0% ..  but it seems the Product Tax Class is still over-riding, even if I change Priority on both.  Any ideas?

html: @jonovate should work pretty much exactly like this.
text: @jonovate should work pretty much exactly like this.

html: Use TaxRule.override_group to determine what happens for the products with 8.25% tax and the customer belongs to “Tax exempt”-group. TaxRule.override_group: if several rules match, only the rules with the highest override group number will be effective. This can be used, for example, to implement tax exemption by adding a rule with very high override group that sets a zero tax.
text: Use `TaxRule.override_group` to determine what happens for the products with 8.25% tax and the customer belongs to “Tax exempt”-group. `TaxRule.override_group`: if several rules match, only the rules with the highest override group number will be effective.  This can be used, for example, to implement tax exemption by adding a rule with very high override group that sets a zero tax.

[![Screen Shot 2019-04-01 at 5.42.04 PM.png](https://files.gitter.im/shuup/shuup/5RVe/thumb/Screen-Shot-2019-04-01-at-5.42.04-PM.png)](https://files.gitter.im/shuup/shuup/5RVe/Screen-Shot-2019-04-01-at-5.42.04-PM.png)

html: I setup 2 products with different tax class. Then I created these 3 rules for those 2 tax classes with exception that when the customer belongs to “Retail tax group” taxes are exempted. Works here. When not logged in I get the tax for my product and when logged in the tax is exempted for the product normally having that ~8% tax. Since you created custom tax group make sure your current contact also has been added to this group.

html: @critiquecom since you are working on workbench you might want to forget that addons-management admin. It works best when not in debug/dev-mode. For example the app reload has issues when using “runserver”. You could just pip install the at command line and then add the “shuup_mailchimp” to installed apps (do not forget to migrate too). If you do not want to add changes to workbench base settings and you do not have local settings defined then you can add the app name to this file and restart the server.
text: @critiquecom since you are working on workbench you might want to forget that addons-management admin. It works best when not in debug/dev-mode. For example the app reload has issues when using “runserver”. You could just pip install the at command line and then add the “shuup_mailchimp” to installed apps (do not forget to migrate too). If you do not want to add changes to workbench base settings and you do not have local settings defined then you can add the app name to [this file](https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup_workbench/settings/base_settings.py#L21.) and restart the server.

html:
def configure(setup):
    setup.INSTALLED_APPS = list(setup.INSTALLED_APPS) + [
        "shuup_mailchimp"
    ]

    setup.DATABASES = {
        "default": {
            "ENGINE": "django.db.backends.mysql",
            "NAME": "shuup",
            "USER": "root",
            "PASSWORD": "root",
            "HOST": "localhost",
            "PORT": "3306",
            "OPTIONS": {}
        }
    }
SImple local_settings.py. Place this next to the shuup_workbench.base_settings.py.
text: SImple `local_settings.py`. Place this next to the `shuup_workbench.base_settings.py`.

html:
@tulimaki and @chessbr Thanks the feedback regarding mailchimp integration. I had naively assumed the integration strategy for MailChimp and Stripe were identical. I have since learnt that MailChimp integration creates an entry under the Settings menu in the SA left hand menu. I have since configured the settings with my MailChimp credentials plus separately set up a notification script for payment confirmation. Two issues: 1) Clicking the "Save and Test" configuration displays "Success" almost instantaneously which to me implies I am not connecting with MailChimp remote API. 2) I note the Django Settings contains a backend entry EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django.core.mail.backends.console.EmailBackend' As a diagnostic step I replaced this with EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django.core.mail.backends.filebased.EmailBackend'
EMAIL_FILE_PATH = '/tmp/app-messages' As expected the file updated with the message text. But I still am not sending the the email message through/from MailChimp. The email message is nor being received by emaili hosting provider. Questions: Are there additional MailChimp parameters I need to add to the Django settings file? I presume I dont need to setup a special SMTP mail server because I am interfacing to the MailChiimp API? What diagnostic steps should I take to find out the problem with 1) and 2) .How can I be sure that I am connecting with the mailchimp API from the Shuup priogramme running under runserver? Chris
text:
@tulimaki  and @chessbr  Thanks the feedback regarding mailchimp integration. I had naively assumed the integration strategy for MailChimp and Stripe were identical. I have since learnt that MailChimp integration creates an entry under the Settings menu in the SA left hand menu. I have since configured the settings with my MailChimp credentials plus separately set up a notification script for payment confirmation. Two issues: 1) Clicking the "Save and Test" configuration displays "Success" almost instantaneously which to me implies I am not connecting with MailChimp remote API. 2) I note the Django Settings contains a backend entry EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django.core.mail.backends.console.EmailBackend' As a diagnostic step I replaced this with EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django.core.mail.backends.filebased.EmailBackend'
EMAIL_FILE_PATH = '/tmp/app-messages'  As expected the file updated with the message text. But I still am not sending the the email message through/from MailChimp. The email message is nor being received by emaili hosting provider. Questions: Are there additional MailChimp parameters I need to add to the Django settings file?  I presume I dont need to setup a special SMTP mail server because I am interfacing to the MailChiimp  API? What diagnostic steps should I take to find out the problem with 1) and 2) .How can I be sure that I am connecting with the mailchimp API from the Shuup  priogramme running under runserver? Chris

html: @critiquecom Hi! Mailchimp integration is not a email backend to use MailChimp. That is just an integration to subscribe users to a mail list in MailChimp. It also provides a plugin to add in themes which users can use to subscribe to newsletter. The email backend should be done separately.
text: @critiquecom Hi! Mailchimp integration is not a email backend to use MailChimp. That is just an integration to subscribe users to a mail list in MailChimp. It also provides a plugin to add in themes which users can use to subscribe to newsletter. The email backend should be done separately.

html: @critiquecom Hi! Shuup uses Django email library to send emails, so it is just Django :) Just configure the email backend to something you want (like Mandril) and that's it. I tried to find some updated Mandril Django email backend but I couldn't, maybe you just need to create a simple one :) use this as a base https://djrill.readthedocs.io/en/v2.1/
text: @critiquecom Hi! Shuup uses Django email library to send emails, so it is just Django :) Just configure the email backend to something you want (like Mandril) and that's it. I tried to find some updated Mandril Django email backend but I couldn't, maybe you just need to create a simple one :) use this as a base https://djrill.readthedocs.io/en/v2.1/

html: @chessbr and @tulimaki Hello again. Yes this advice was helpful. I added the following Django backend EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django.core.mail.backends.smtp.EmailBackend' to the base settings file. I then installed the well known Django-debug-toolbar. This assisted me to track the programme flow path to Shuup/shuup/notify/actions/ email.py.. At this point the programme errors "Connection Refused" I am assuming this is the point where the MailChimp integration occurs. I have installed Shuup-MailChimp. html: How can we add a new currency support? In fact we want to add BDT as currency and BN (bangla) as language support. Please guide us
text: How can we add a new currency support? In fact we want to add BDT as currency and BN (bangla) as language support. Please guide us

html:
@ershadul Navigate to /sa/currencies/ add new by using the lSO-4217 currency code. Then navigate to shops management at /sa/shops/. Currency is per shop and making it per order would require some magic.

To add BN as language option you can request bangla as langauge option at Transifex. After that you can translate it and let us know when it is translated (or pull those translations yourself and create pull request for those).

Second option for adding new language is to use python -m shuup_workbench shuup_makemessages -l <language_code> this adds the translation files to Shuup. After this edit those files. For editing those translations you can use either text-editor of your choice, but also for example (this)[https://poedit.net/]. After you have translated the language create pull request so you do not need hold those translations in your local copy. Final step to test these translations would be to update your project settings and run python -m shuup_workbench compilemessages.

html:
@yurb_gitlab Hi! Use this CLI to generate the project template for you: npm i -g shuup-cli, then:

1) Create a new folder: mkdir my-theme

2) Enter inside the folder and run: shuup-cli.. follow the steps (just select the theme template) and that's it, a base theme will be created.

3) You can then install your theme inside your virtualenv to test: pip install -e /path/to/my-theme/

4) Add my_theme (or the name you choose) to your INSTALLED_APPS

5) Start changing/adding the templates to your custom theme project
text:
@yurb_gitlab Hi! Use this CLI to generate the project template for you: `npm i -g shuup-cli`, then:

1) Create a new folder: `mkdir my-theme`

2) Enter inside the folder and run: `shuup-cli`.. follow the steps (just select the theme template) and that's it, a base theme will be created.

3) You can then install your theme inside your virtualenv to test: `pip install -e /path/to/my-theme/`

4) Add `my_theme` (or the name you choose) to your INSTALLED_APPS

5) Start changing/adding the templates to your custom theme project

html:
Hello!

I want to integrate DaData (https://dadata.ru/en/ - the address normalization service) on the checkout page.
That is, instead of the standard form for filling the address (see below 'Standart form'), I should have a custom form for filling the address in one line and a hidden form for the payment address. Something like this: 'New form', 'Form with suggestions'.

As far as I understand, there are three ways to implement this:

  1. Using the provider "front_service_checkout_phase_provider" to change the checkout phase
  2. Change the view via SHUUP_CHECKOUT_VIEW_SPEC setting
  3. Change the address form via SHUUP_ADDRESS_MODEL_FORM setting

Which way is prefer?
text:

html:
@yurb_gitlab you can create a template tag to get product attribute by identifier like this:

@library.global_function
def get_attribute_value(product, attr_identifier):
    product_attribute = ProductAttribute.objects.filter(
        product=product,
        attribute__identifier=attr_identifier
    ).first()
    return product_attribute.formatted_value if product_attribute else None

Then in template you would just use: {{ get_attribute_value(product, "my-attribute-identifier") }}
@yurb_gitlab that is perfect!

@yurb_gitlab

What would be the least-intrusive strategy to override the ChooseToRegister form referenced here?

Customise the checkout method, that's it :)

@dansamara Hi!

If you want custom configuration on a ShippingMethod level, you can do something like I did to Brazilian Postal services called Correios:

The Carrier has types of services, like Express, 24Hours etc and they are just service options: https://github.com/chessbr/shuup-correios/blob/master/shuup_correios/models.py#L35
Based on that, when a shipping method is created, it adds a custom BehaviorComponent https://github.com/chessbr/shuup-correios/blob/master/shuup_correios/models.py#L54 with the service identifier you select. The CorreiosBehaviorComponent will react based on all the settings set for that behavior component on a ShippingMethod.

If you want custom configuration for the entire Carrier, you can also add custom fields to your Carrier model like we do on the Stripe PaymentProcessor https://github.com/shuup/shuup-stripe/blob/master/shuup_stripe/models.py#L16 , then you just need to configure it when creating the service
text:
@dansamara Hi! 

If you want custom configuration on a ShippingMethod level, you can do something like I did to Brazilian Postal services called Correios:

The Carrier has types of services, like Express, 24Hours etc and they are just service options: https://github.com/chessbr/shuup-correios/blob/master/shuup_correios/models.py#L35
Based on that, when a shipping method is created, it adds a custom BehaviorComponent https://github.com/chessbr/shuup-correios/blob/master/shuup_correios/models.py#L54 with the service identifier you select. The CorreiosBehaviorComponent will react based on all the settings set for that behavior component on a ShippingMethod.

If you want custom configuration for the entire Carrier, you can also add custom fields to your Carrier model like we do on the Stripe PaymentProcessor https://github.com/shuup/shuup-stripe/blob/master/shuup_stripe/models.py#L16 , then you just need to configure it when creating the service

text: Nikita Y. @FMajesty       here,  https://pypi.org/project/shuup-stripe/ you can download the file, then, go to addons in the main menu of the admin panel, and then, upload the file, which is in the wheels format, then, click to install it. html:
@FMajesty you can also pip install shuup-stripe and add it to your project installed apps manually. With workbench edit either base or local-settings.

Something like this for local_settings.py should do it:

def configure(setup):
    setup.INSTALLED_APPS = list(setup.INSTALLED_APPS) + ["shuup_stripe"]

html: @yurb_gitlab if this functionality is per shipping method and not address. Then you can provide custom dynamic checkouphase which is applied when certain shipping method is selected. Here you can find example https://github.com/shuup/shuup-stripe/blob/master/shuup_stripe/apps.py#L17, https://github.com/shuup/shuup-stripe/blob/master/shuup_stripe/checkout_phase.py#L91. With shipping method the custom checkout phase works exactly same way as with payments. If you look that Stripe example you would then store your additional information to that shipping data.

html: @tech1and lxml package is not installing correctly. Install it separately before installing Shuup. For Windows easiest way to install lxml would be with wheel from here. Download wheel and then you can just pip install <path-to-whl.whl>. You should likely also install lxml outside your virtual environment so you might need to re-create your environment after this.
text: @tech1and lxml package is not installing correctly. Install it separately before installing Shuup. For Windows easiest way to install lxml would be [with wheel from here](https://www.lfd.uci.edu/~gohlke/pythonlibs/#lxml). Download wheel and then you can just `pip install <path-to-whl.whl>`. You should likely also install lxml outside your virtual environment so you might need to re-create your environment after this.

text:
Sorry if this has been asked a million times before. But since its not clearly mentioned on the website I am asking here explicitly - 
*multivendor solution is not available in open-source*. Please confirm. Thanks!

html: @nsangwan our multivendor solution is not available in OS version, but you surely can implement your own over it. Basically vendors are suppliers and you would need to “just” implement some admin module for vendors to manage their products and stocks. In theory you as a superuser admin you could manage products for all vendors. This logic here defines how supplier/vendor is selected for front/order line. This here would define the currently active vendor for admin and is the key part for defining admin modules for vendors.
text: @nsangwan our multivendor solution is not available in OS version, but you surely can implement your own over it. Basically vendors are suppliers and you would need to “just” implement some admin module for vendors to manage their products and stocks. In theory you as a superuser admin you could manage products for all vendors. This logic [here](https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/core/models/_product_shops.py#L600) defines how supplier/vendor is selected for front/order line. This [here](https://github.com/shuup/shuup/blob/master/shuup/admin/supplier_provider.py#L17) would define the currently active vendor for admin and is the key part for defining admin modules for vendors.

html: So basically what our multivendor solution does is define multiple vendor admin module and slightly more advanced way to get supplier for the shop product.
text: So basically what our multivendor solution does is define multiple vendor admin module and slightly more advanced way to get supplier for the shop product.

text:
Hi! I have a question, I changed the language to Spanish on my site and when I want to enter a product, I get this error "DoesNotExist at /p/10-beard-stash-oil/.
sales unit does not have a translation for the current language!
sales unit ID #1, language=es (tried fallbacks es)
Attempted to read attribute symbol." 
If anyone can help me set this up. Thank you!

html: @mailencardoso Hi! I guess you changed Django settings after you ran the first migration and setup. You should first make sure the languages in settings are the ones you want and then run migrations and shuup_init. The first objects will be created using the default language from settings. You probably need to add the en language to LANGUAGES to bypass that error. You can also do a manual database fix by replacing all en values to es
text: @mailencardoso Hi! I guess you changed Django settings after you ran the first migration and setup.  You should first make sure the languages in settings are the ones you want and then run migrations and shuup_init. The first objects will be created using the default language from settings. You probably need to add the `en` language to LANGUAGES to bypass that error. You can also do a manual database fix by replacing all `en` values to `es`

html: Here is example for all language related settings. That is important PARLER_DEFAULT_LANGUAGE_CODE.
text: Here is example for all language related settings. That is important PARLER_DEFAULT_LANGUAGE_CODE.
